title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To study the influence of the local microenvironment on tumour invasion
outcome: we applied spatially resolved transcriptomics and single-cell RNA sequencing (scRNA-seq) to a transgenic zebrafish model of BRAFV600E-driven melanoma (Fig. 1a)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Across fish, we found a conserved ‘interface’ transcriptional cell state that occurs where tumour cells invade into the microenvironment (12.1% of zebrafish tumour cells; Fig. 1a)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To investigate whether these interface cells occur in patients
outcome: we analysed a recently published human melanoma scRNA-seq dataset of 7,186 tumour and stromal cells from 31 patients with untreated or immunotherapy-resistant melanoma7 (Fig. 1b and Extended Data Fig. 1a)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: a subpopulation of human tumour cells highly upregulated interface markers (12.3% of tumour cells; Fig. 1c and Extended Data Fig. 1b), mostly from immunotherapy-resistant patients (Extended Data Fig. 1d–f)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: To better understand the nature of these cells
context: A previous study defined at least four cell states that encompass the melanoma differentiation trajectory (melanocytic, transitory, neural crest-like and undifferentiated)2
outcome: we compared our interface population to human melanoma cell states

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Although tumour cells were relatively evenly distributed between the four cell states, interface cells showed clear upregulation of genes characteristic of the undifferentiated state (Fig. 1d,e and Extended Data Fig. 1c)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Interface cells downregulated MITF and SOX10 and upregulated SOX9 (Fig. 1f and Extended Data Fig. 1g). Classical melanocyte pigmentation genes were minimally expressed by interface cells relative to the tumour bulk, including MITF (log2 fold change (FC) = −5.19), TYRP1 (log2FC = −7.75) and PMEL (log2FC = −8.78) (Fig. 1f, Extended Data Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1). Unexpectedly, interface cells also upregulated genes involved in neuronal development, including SOX11 (log2FC = 5.15), NNAT (log2FC = 8.61), NEUROD1 (log2FC = 6.22) and NEFM (log2FC = 6.19) (Fig. 1g and Supplementary Table 1)
context: The transition between the proliferative and invasive states is regulated by the transcription factors MITF, SOX9 and SOX10, among others8. MITF and SOX10 regulate melanocyte differentiation and proliferation9,10, whereas SOX9 is associated with the undifferentiated invasive state11
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: Tumour gene expression altered by TME
main_content: Gene set enrichment analysis (GSEA) revealed that transcriptional programs linked to cell fate specification and neuronal development were highly enriched in interface cells (Fig. 1h,i)
outcome: These data indicate that interface cells adopt an invasive state with markers of neuronal development

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To examine factors within the local TME that may drive the interface state
outcome: we performed histology on tissue sections from our transgenic zebrafish melanoma model, focusing on the invasive front

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Tumour cells invading into the TME showed elongated nuclei compared with the bulk tumour mass (Fig. 1j,k)
context: A previous study showed that tumour nuclei become highly elongated when squeezing through mechanically restrictive environments12
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: we hypothesized that mechanical forces exerted on the cell/nucleus may cause stable changes in gene expression and tumour cell behaviour
context: Although numerous factors probably influence tumour invasion
outcome: To test this hypothesis, we adapted a system to confine human melanoma cells (A375 cell line) in vitro at predefined heights (3 µm) using a polydimethylsiloxane piston and micropatterned coverslips13 (Fig. 1l)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confinement in vitro was not cytotoxic because confined cells did not upregulate apoptosis markers cleaved caspase-3, annexin V or cleaved PARP (Extended Data Fig. 2a–f). Post-confinement, cells recovered typical morphology within 24 h without widespread cell death (Extended Data Fig. 2g)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To profile confinement-induced changes in gene expression
outcome: we confined A375 cells for approximately 18 h and performed bulk RNA-seq

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Principal component analysis revealed considerable transcriptional alterations induced by confinement (Fig. 1m and Supplementary Table 2). Similar to human interface cells, confined cells upregulated several neuronal pathways (Fig. 1n and Supplementary Table 2).
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Pathway analysis showed that many of the co-regulated genes were related to neuronal development (Extended Data Fig. 2i and Supplementary Table 3)
outcome: These data indicate that confinement causes interface cells to adopt a neuronal identity

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We hypothesized that melanoma cells hijack neuronal mechanisms to allow them to invade into the mechanically confined microenvironment
context: Recent reports indicate that the MT cytoskeleton is stabilized by force to protect confined cells from damage16
outcome: We used our in vitro confinement system to characterize how force remodels the MT cytoskeleton by imaging A375 cells labelled with the MT vital dye SiR-tubulin

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confinement extensively remodelled the MT cytoskeleton; within 2–4 h, curved MTs began encircling the cell and nuclear periphery (Fig. 2a,b)
context: This was reminiscent of a previous study that showed that MTs bend to prevent buckling or rupture in response to force16
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We also observed loss of a central MT organizing centre with radial MTs
context: reminiscent of neurons with centrosome-independent MT organization14,17
outcome: These results indicate that confined melanoma cells rapidly undergo structural changes in the MT cytoskeleton resembling neurons

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: observed enrichment of acetylated tubulin at the tumour border6 (Fig. 2c–e)
context: Acetylated tubulin mediates neuronal architecture and function and marks axonal MTs18. Tubulin acetylation stabilizes MTs and thus the cell against mechanical pressure19. Curved MTs, such as those we observed in confined cells (Fig. 2a,b), are also indicative of long-lived, stabilized MTs19
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confining A375 cells in vitro also resulted in significant upregulation of acetylated tubulin (P = 6.86 × 10−12; Fig. 2f–h). Acetylated tubulin filaments in unconfined cells were typically short and linear, whereas in confined cells, acetylated tubulin filaments were longer and more curved—again indicative of stabilization (Fig. 2f,g)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We noticed that in confined cells, the hyperacetylated tubulin network was often perinuclear (Fig. 2f,g) and hypothesized that this network may provide structural support to the nucleus
context: As the stiffest and largest organelle, the nucleus is vulnerable to confinement-induced stress, with confined migration often causing nuclear envelope rupture and DNA damage20,21. During migration through confined spaces, neurons assemble a perinuclear network of acetylated tubulin to protect the nucleus22,23
outcome: We confirmed the stability of the perinuclear MT network by treating confined cells with nocodazole

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Nocodazole (1 µM) induced the disassembly of almost all non-modified tubulin filaments in both unconfined and confined cells (Fig. 2i,j). Although unconfined nocodazole-treated cells exhibited minimal acetylated tubulin, many confined nocodazole-treated cells contained a perinuclear acetylated tubulin cage (Fig. 2i,j)
context: which induces MT disassembly through an acetylation-independent mechanism24. Acetylated MTs are resistant to nocodazole19
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We generated a stable A375 cell line, in which the main eukaryotic tubulin acetyltransferase (ATAT1) was inactivated using CRISPR (Extended Data Fig. 3a,b)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: found that this almost completely abolished acetylated tubulin, including the perinuclear network (Extended Data Fig. 3c–e)
outcome: This indicates that ATAT1 is the acetyltransferase that responds to mechanical stress in melanoma cells by stabilizing the tubulin cytoskeleton

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To clarify the composition of the perinuclear tubulin network
context: In addition to acetylation, MTs exhibit a variety of post-translational modifications (PTMs), including tyrosination, glutamylation, glycylation and methylation, which influence MT stability25
outcome: we used immunofluorescence to characterize MT PTMs in confined melanoma cells

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: most MTs in confined and unconfined A375 cells were highly tyrosinated (Extended Data Fig. 4a–d)
context: Detyrosination has been linked to stabilized MTs26... probably owing to the high concentrations of tyrosine and tyrosinase in melanoma27
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: there was no specific enrichment of these PTMs in the perinuclear network, as observed for acetylated MTs. Similar results were observed for polyglutamylated MTs (Extended Data Fig. 4e,f). No polyglycylated MTs were found in either condition (Extended Data Fig. 4g,h)
outcome: This indicates that acetylation is the primary PTM mediating the assembly and/or stability of the perinuclear tubulin network. These data indicate that confined melanoma cells assemble a stable perinuclear tubulin network to reinforce the nucleus against mechanical stress, similar to neurons.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: to identify potential confinement-induced mediators of this state
outcome: We examined our zebrafish and human transcriptomic datasets

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Interface cells consistently upregulated high mobility group (HMG)-family proteins (Fig. 3a)
context: which regulate chromatin architecture by binding and bending DNA to relieve mechanical strain28. Although HMG-enriched transcriptional programs are upregulated across many tumour types, including melanoma29, their contribution to tumour progression remains poorly understood
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We focused on HMGB2 (zebrafish hmgb2a and hmgb2b)
context: because it was the most upregulated HMG family member in interface cells from zebrafish (Fig. 3a,b), and because our previous study identified HMGB2 as a signalling factor enriched in interface cells6
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: HMGB2 was also highly upregulated by human interface cells (P = 3.24 × 10−37; Fig. 3c,d and Extended Data Fig. 1h)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To validate our transcriptomic results indicating that HMGB2 is upregulated at the invasive front
outcome: we examined HMGB2 expression in zebrafish melanoma tissue sections

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: In invading tumour cells, HMGB2 was only upregulated in elongated or misshaped tumour cells that appeared to be under mechanical pressure from adjacent tissues (Fig. 3e–g). HMGB2 concentrations were inversely correlated to nuclear circularity (R = −0.474; P = 1.19 × 10−12; Fig. 3g)
outcome: indicating that confinement induces HMGB2 upregulation

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Similarly, the in vitro confinement of A375 human melanoma cells caused nuclear HMGB2 intensity to approximately double relative to unconfined cells (P = 1.42 × 10−7; Fig. 3h,i). This increase was not solely attributable to changes in nuclear density; although Hoechst intensity also slightly increased upon confinement (probably owing to compaction of chromatin/the nucleus; P = 0.0017; Fig. 3j), normalizing HMGB2 to Hoechst concentrations still showed a significant increase (P = 3.01 × 10−6; Fig. 3k)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: nuclear HMGB2–GFP concentrations increased linearly over approximately 16 h (0.269 ± 0.020-fold per hour) to a final concentration of 1.76 ± 0.072-fold relative to initial concentrations (Extended Data Fig. 5a,b)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: quantified no change in their expression upon confinement (Extended Data Fig. 5c–f)
outcome: indicating that confinement-induced upregulation of HMGB2 is not a general property of all HMG family members

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: to look for evidence of interface cells with elongated nuclei, high HMGB2 concentrations and perinuclear acetylated tubulin
outcome: We examined a human melanoma tissue microarray

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: As in the zebrafish, the invasive front in human samples often contained elongated nuclei with high HMGB2 and acetylated tubulin expression, although with expected interpatient variability (Extended Data Fig. 6a–e). Of the 40 patient samples analysed, 20 (50%) contained putative interface cells (elongated nuclei, HMGB2+ and AcTub+)
outcome: This validates our scRNA-seq analyses, indicating that interface cells are present in human samples (Fig. 1c)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We then investigated whether the upregulation of HMGB2 and acetylated tubulin by confined cells is melanoma-specific or exhibited across other cancer types
context: We focused on two cancer types probably influenced by mechanical stress in vivo: pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma and bladder cancer
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: In both, confinement induced significant upregulation of HMGB2 and acetylated tubulin (Extended Data Fig. 6f–q)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To rule out a potential pro-invasive role for these transcription factors upon mechanical stress in melanoma
context: Mechanical stress can be associated with nuclear translocation of transcription factors, such as YAP, as well as epithelial–mesenchymal transition inducers, including Twist, Snail and SMAD3 (ref. 30)
outcome: we quantified their expression in confined A375 cells

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: None of the factors examined (YAP, Twist, Snail and SMAD3) exhibited nuclear translocation upon confinement, and the nuclear expression of YAP, Twist and SMAD3 decreased (Extended Data Fig. 7)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To investigate how mechanical confinement induces HMGB2 upregulation
context: hypothesizing that the perinuclear acetylated tubulin network (Fig. 2f,g) may propagate confinement-induced force to the nucleus
outcome: we focused on the MT cytoskeleton

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Upon confining two different A375–HMGB2KO cell lines, we confirmed that the perinuclear acetylated tubulin network was unaffected (Extended Data Fig. 8d,e)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: to determine whether the acetylated tubulin network influences HMGB2 upregulation
context: Tubulin acetylation is mediated by the acetyltransferase ATAT1 (ref. 31) and deacetylation by HDAC6 (ref. 32)
outcome: We modulated tubulin dynamics and acetylation state in confined cells

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We first treated A375 cells with the HDAC6 inhibitor tubacin33, which increased tubulin acetylation without affecting histone acetylation (Extended Data Fig. 9a–f)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: In confined cells, tubacin treatment significantly increased both total nuclear HMGB2 accumulation (P = 1.1646 × 10−6; Extended Data Fig. 9g,h) and the rate of accumulation, which approximately doubled versus controls (0.353 ± 0.0364-fold per hour versus 0.145 ± 0.0171-fold per hour; P = 1.1589 × 10−6; Extended Data Fig. 9i)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To stabilize MTs independent of acetylation
context: Taxol... binds β-tubulin and prevents tubulin monomer incorporation into MT filaments and thus should not influence the acetylation state of HMGB2 or other proteins34
outcome: we treated confined cells with paclitaxel (Taxol)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Taxol (100 nM) significantly increased HMGB2 accumulation in confined cells (P = 0.00230; Extended Data Fig. 9g,h), with an accumulation rate remarkably similar to tubacin-treated cells (0.338 ± 0.0425-fold per hour versus 0.353 ± 0.0364-fold per hour; P = 0.961; Extended Data Fig. 9i)
outcome: indicate that confinement-induced HMGB2 enrichment is linked to MT stability, rather than acetylation state or other HDAC6 functions

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To confirm the role of perinuclear acetylated tubulin in mediating HMGB2 accumulation
context: Nocodazole abolishes most MT networks, with the exception of stabilized acetylated tubulin filaments24
outcome: we treated A375[HMGB2–GFP] cells with nocodazole before applying confinement

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We observed near total loss of visible SiR-tubulin signal in confined nocodazole-treated cells (Extended Data Fig. 9j), whereas the perinuclear acetylated tubulin network remained intact (Fig. 2i,j) and HMGB2–GFP accumulation was unaffected (P = 0.714; Extended Data Fig. 9k,l)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We quantified HMGB2 accumulation in confined A375–ATAT1KO cells lacking acetylated tubulin (Extended Data Fig. 3c–e)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Unexpectedly, HMGB2 accumulation was not impaired in ATAT1KO cells (Extended Data Fig. 3f)
outcome: suggesting that acetylated tubulin is sufficient but not necessary for the enrichment of HMGB2 in response to confinement

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: we investigated other factors that may cooperate with the MT cytoskeleton to promote upregulation of HMGB2 in confined cells
outcome: using TurboID35 to perform proximity labelling proteomics targeting HMGB2 interactors (Fig. 3l and Supplementary Table 4)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: One highly enriched protein was nesprin 2 (gene name: SYNE2), a component of the linker of nucleoskeleton and cytoskeleton (LINC) complex that connects the cytoskeleton, nuclear lamina and chromatin36 (Fig. 3m and Supplementary Table 4)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We hypothesized that nesprin 2 may be required for enrichment of HMGB2 upon confinement
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Accordingly, confined A375 cells upregulated nesprin 2 (Extended Data Fig. 10a,b), and targeting SYNE2 with short interfering RNA (siRNA) (Extended Data Fig. 10c) abolished the confinement-mediated accumulation of HMGB2 (Fig. 3n,o) and perinuclear tubulin network (Fig. 3p,q)
outcome: This indicates that nesprin 2 and the tubulin cytoskeleton interact to upregulate HMGB2

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Lamin A/C increased by approximately 3-fold in confined cells (P = 1.28 × 10−162; Extended Data Fig. 10d,e)
context: The LINC complex cooperates with the nuclear lamina to tune nuclear stiffness36
outcome: suggesting that the nuclear lamina was remodelled in response to confinement

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: showing increased nuclear stiffness in confined cells (Extended Data Fig. 10f,g)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: Together, our results demonstrate that confined melanoma cells remodel cytoskeletal and nuclear structures to reinforce the cell against mechanical force, resulting in LINC complex-mediated HMGB2 upregulation and nuclear stiffening.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: We used fluorescence recovery after photobleaching (FRAP) to characterize nuclear HMGB2 dynamics upon confinement

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: HMGB2–GFP was highly dynamic even in unconfined cells (Fig. 4a–d), with only approximately 25% stably bound within the nucleus (mobile fraction = 75.21 ± 0.91%)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: In both conditions, FRAP recovery curves fitted well to a two-component exponential equation (average coefficient of determination (R2) = 0.986 ± 0.00054; Fig. 4d,e and Methods)
outcome: indicating two pools of nuclear HMGB2: fast-diffusing (stochastic interactions with chromatin) and slower-diffusing (more specific, stable interactions)39

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Although more than 90% of HMGB2 remained fast-diffusing in both conditions, confinement significantly increased the proportion of slower-diffusing HMGB2 (6.76 ± 0.39% versus 4.21 ± 0.39%; P = 1.134 × 10−5; Fig. 4f)
outcome: suggesting more specific, stable HMGB2–chromatin interactions in confined cells

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: we propose that this could affect chromatin accessibility
context: Our FRAP analysis indicates that confinement upregulates HMGB2 and stabilizes its interactions with chromatin
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Assay for transposase-accessible chromatin (ATAC) sequencing (ATAC-seq) of A375 cells overexpressing HMGB2 showed broadly increased chromatin accessibility (Fig. 4g)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Peak-gene mapping and pathway analysis revealed that open chromatin regions were highly enriched for neuronal genes, with increased accessibility at loci linked to the neural crest and neuronal development (Fig. 4h–j and Supplementary Table 5)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Homer de novo motif analysis identified conserved transcription factor binding motifs enriched within the promoter of open chromatin regions upon HMGB2 overexpression (HMGB2OE). The top-ranked motif was an AP-1 motif (Fig. 4k; P = 1 × 10−49)
context: implicated in melanoma and melanocyte plasticity40,41
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Other highly ranked motifs included PRDM4 (Fig. 4k; P = 1 × 10−12), and SOX9 (Fig. 4k; P = 1 × 10−11)
context: which functions in neural development42... a critical regulator of the pro-invasive phenotype switch in melanoma43
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: These data indicate that HMGB2 upregulation increases chromatin accessibility at loci associated with plasticity and a neuronal phenotype, promoting a confinement-induced dedifferentiation program.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To clarify potential HMGB2 targets
outcome: we performed chromatin immunoprecipitation (ChIP) sequencing (ChIP–seq) targeting HMGB2 in A375 cells using a double-crosslinking approach44 (Extended Data Fig. 11a)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: we identified a final high-confidence set of 96 targets (Extended Data Fig. 11b and Supplementary Table 6)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We observed HMGB2 binding at promoter regions of several AP-1 signalling genes, including FOSL1, JUNB and JUND (Extended Data Fig. 11c and Supplementary Table 6)
outcome: validating our ATAC-seq results and supporting the pro-invasive role of HMGB2

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Several neuronal genes were also identified as HMGB2 targets, including NOTCH2, NOTCH2NLC, TBX6, GBA1 and ZNF335 (Extended Data Fig. 11d and Supplementary Table 6), as well as pro-tumorigenic genes such as KMT2A (Extended Data Fig. 11e and Supplementary Table 6)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To examine the transcriptional effects
outcome: we performed bulk RNA-seq on A375 cells stably overexpressing HMGB2 (Extended Data Fig. 11f)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: HMGB2OE cells adopted a mesenchymal-like and invasive morphology relative to empty vector controls (Extended Data Fig. 11g)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: The most highly upregulated gene was UNC5D, a netrin receptor promoting neuronal survival and migration47 (Extended Data Fig. 11h and Supplementary Table 7). Other upregulated neuronal genes included DCC, SH3GL2 and NPX2 (Extended Data Fig. 11h,i and Supplementary Table 7)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: GSEA revealed an overrepresentation of neuronal genes within enriched pathways (Extended Data Fig. 11j,k and Supplementary Table 7)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: several invasive genes were also upregulated (MAGEA1, SPP1, CTAG2 and GDF6; Extended Data Fig. 11i and Supplementary Table 7)
outcome: Supporting a pro-invasive role for HMGB2

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: (missing)
outcome: These data indicate that HMGB2 alters chromatin architecture to promote an invasive neuronal state.

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 drives invasion through Notch and BRN2
main_content: We investigated whether HMGB2 drives invasion through these factors
context: Phenotypic plasticity in melanoma is controlled by a regulatory axis of melanocytic transcription factors (MITF) driving proliferation versus invasive factors (BRN2, SOX9 and AP-1) that also slow proliferation
outcome: Using the SKMEL5 melanocytic cell line, we created a stable line expressing V5-tagged HMGB2 and performed ChIP–seq targeting V5 and HMGB2 (Extended Data Fig. 12a)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 drives invasion through Notch and BRN2
main_content: We identified robust HMGB2 binding to the MITF promoter (Extended Data Fig. 12c). However, loss of HMGB2 did not meaningfully alter MITF expression (log2FC = 0.157; Extended Data Fig. 12e–g and Supplementary Table 9)
outcome: indicating that HMGB2 may regulate pro-invasive factors instead

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 drives invasion through Notch and BRN2
main_content: HMGB2 robustly bound the promoter of Notch signalling genes in both A375 (Extended Data Fig. 11d and Supplementary Table 6) and SKMEL5 (Extended Data Fig. 12d and Supplementary Table 8) cells. Notch family genes were also upregulated by human interface cells (DLL1, DLL3 and DLK2; Supplementary Table 1) and confined human melanoma cells (NOTCH2NLA, DLK2 and DLL4; Supplementary Table 2).
context: Notch signalling promotes melanoma invasion through brain-2 (BRN2, also known as POU3F2) (ref. 48), a well-characterized pro-invasive transcription factor in melanoma49 that also functions in neuronal development50
outcome: This indicates that invasive and neuronal phenotypes in confined interface cells are induced by HMGB2-mediated upregulation of Notch/BRN2 signalling

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 drives invasion through Notch and BRN2
main_content: a BRN2/POU3F2 motif was enriched in the promoter region of HMGB2 target genes (Extended Data Fig. 12h)
outcome: Supporting this model

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Confined A375 cells downregulated many proliferation-related pathways (Fig. 5b)
context: One prediction of the melanoma phenotype switching model is the trade-off between opposing phenotypes; highly proliferative cells are less invasive, whereas highly invasive cells are less proliferative (Fig. 5a). Our data indicate that confinement-induced upregulation of HMGB2 could mediate this phenotypic plasticity.
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To visualize the influence of confinement on this trade-off
outcome: we generated an A375 cell line stably expressing the FastFUCCI cell cycle sensor54

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Upon confinement, all initially mitotic cells (mAG+ and S/G2–M phase) rapidly lost mAG fluorescence, indicating cell cycle exit (Fig. 5c,d)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To directly test the role of HMGB2 in melanoma invasion
outcome: we used in vitro invasion assays (Fig. 5e)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: found that targeting HMGB2 with siRNA significantly impaired invasion (P = 0.0133; Fig. 5f,g), whereas overexpression of HMGB2 increased invasion (P = 0.0180; Fig. 5h,i)
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We quantified minimal migration of confined A375 cells (mean velocity = 0.0838 ± 0.0025 µm min−1; Extended Data Fig. 13a–c)
context: Previous studies identified a fast amoeboid mode of migration induced by confinement and low adhesion13,55–57
outcome: which indicates that fast amoeboid migration is not a major contributor to confinement-induced phenotypic plasticity in our system

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: To test the role of HMGB2 in phenotype switching in vivo
outcome: we generated BRAFV600E melanomas in zebrafish, in which zebrafish hmgb2a and hmgb2b were inactivated by CRISPR

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: Loss of hmgb2 and hmgb2b markedly increased melanoma growth, with tumours growing almost 2-fold larger by 10 weeks (P = 0.0193; Fig. 5j–l) while also appearing less invasive than non-targeting controls (Fig. 5m)
outcome: These data indicate that HMGB2 is required for the invasive state, and that its loss pushes melanoma cells towards a hyperproliferative state

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: We investigated the functional domains that control HMGB2 localization and activity in melanoma
context: HMGB family proteins contain three functional domains: A-box and B-box DNA-binding domains and an acidic tail region58 (Extended Data Fig. 14a)
outcome: We assembled constructs with each functional domain removed (Extended Data Fig. 14b) and generated stable A375 cell lines expressing GFP-tagged versions of each (Extended Data Fig. 14c)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: In in vitro proliferation and invasion assays, cells expressing either ΔA-box or ΔB-box constructs were significantly less proliferative (Extended Data Fig. 14d) but more invasive (Extended Data Fig. 14e), even compared to full-length HMGB2
outcome: (missing)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
main_content: there was no significant difference in tumour growth rates (Extended Data Fig. 14h,i) or acetylated tubulin at the invasive front (Extended Data Fig. 14j)
outcome: demonstrating that either HMGB2 DNA-binding domain is sufficient to maintain protein function

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 is associated with drug tolerance
main_content: We examined how the confined invasive state affects therapeutic response
context: Phenotype switching, particularly the undifferentiated/invasive state, has been linked to drug resistance2. This has important clinical relevance because drug-tolerant persister cells are major contributors to relapse59... hypothesizing that the HMGB2-high neuronal state induced by confinement may promote drug tolerance
outcome: To test this, we treated confined cells with Taxol to stabilize MTs

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 is associated with drug tolerance
main_content: Unconfined cells rapidly displayed fragmented nuclear morphology and underwent apoptosis, whereas confined cells were almost completely resistant to Taxol-induced cell death (Extended Data Fig. 13d)
context: Taxol induces cancer cell death through cell cycle arrest60
outcome: indicating that confinement may cause melanoma cells to exit the cell cycle, in accordance with a pro-invasive phenotype switch associated with downregulation of proliferation8

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 is associated with drug tolerance
main_content: We then tested the role of HMGB2 in drug tolerance in vivo
outcome: by transplanting human melanoma cells overexpressing HMGB2 into athymic mice and treating the resulting tumours with dabrafenib and trametinib, widely used targeted therapies in melanoma61 (Fig. 5n)

title: Mechanical confinement governs phenotypic plasticity in melanoma
subsection: HMGB2 is associated with drug tolerance
main_content: HMGB2 overexpression significantly impaired melanoma response to dabrafenib/trametinib in vivo (P = 0.043; Fig. 5o, Extended Data Fig. 13e and Supplementary Table 10)
outcome: Together, our results support a role for confinement-mediated upregulation of HMGB2 inducing a pro-invasive and drug-tolerant state in melanoma (Extended Data Fig. 15)
